titleStmt.title: A great victory obtained by Colonell Jones, and the Parliaments forces at Dublin in Ireland; shewing the manner how they sallyed out of the city upon the Marq. of Ormond, and the Lord Inchiquin, fell upon them neer their trenches, advanced up to their works, put many to the sword and beheaded one, which caused the enemy to cry out and say, that the divell was in the round-heads, for the taking off of heads. Also the Marq. of Ormond's declaration concerning Lieut. Gen. Crumwell, and the protestation of the souldiery thereupon.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 11 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 117550)

titleStmt.title: A great victory obtained by Colonell Jones, and the Parliaments forces at Dublin in Ireland; shewing the manner how they sallyed out of the city upon the Marq. of Ormond, and the Lord Inchiquin, fell upon them neer their trenches, advanced up to their works, put many to the sword and beheaded one, which caused the enemy to cry out and say, that the divell was in the round-heads, for the taking off of heads. Also the Marq. of Ormond's declaration concerning Lieut. Gen. Crumwell, and the protestation of the souldiery thereupon.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Ormonde, James Butler, -- Duke of, 1610-1688 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: A GREAT VICTORY OBTAINED BY Colonell Jones, and the Parliaments Forces at Dublin in Ireland; Å¿hewing the manner how they Å¿allyed out of the City upon the Marq. of Ormond, and the Lord Inchiquin, fell upon them neer their Trenches, advanced up to their Works, put many to the Å¿word, and beheaded one, which cauÅ¿ed the enemy to cry out and Å¿ay, That the Divell was in the Round-heads, for the taking off of heads. AlÅ¿o the Marq. of Ormond's Declaration concerning Lieut. Gen. Crumwell, and the proteÅ¿tation of the Souldiery thereupon.
London, Printed for G. Oreton, and are to be Å¿old neer the Royall Exchange in Cornhill, 1649.

div.head: Bloudy Newes from Dublin in Ireland; containing the particulars of a great Fight between the Princes forces and the Parliaments, the manner how Colonell forces Å¿allyed out of the City and how the King of Scots horÅ¿e purÅ¿ued them towards the Gates.
div.p:
ON Sunday morning laÅ¿t, a party of the Marq. of Ormonds horÅ¿e faced our frontier Guards, keeping a great careering neer the City Walls, and making Å¿everall bold attempts within PiÅ¿tol Å¿hot of our Line, Spurs, and Sconces, which continued for the Å¿pace of half an hour; till at the laÅ¿t Capt. Cambray (Commander in chief of the new Fort) made a Å¿alley out with a party of horÅ¿e and â¢ oor, who placed the MuÅ¿quetiers in an obÅ¿cure trench, for an AmbuÅ¿cado; he himÅ¿elf being the Coy, for the calling in and enÅ¿naring of the adverÅ¿e party; but upon his firÅ¿t advance towards them with his horÅ¿e, he found it a Work very full of difficulty, by reaÅ¿on that they had uÅ¿ed the like point of policp: However, he reÅ¿olved to diÅ¿pute the place, and thereupon divided his horÅ¿e (being 60 in number) into two parties, he himÅ¿elf commanding the one, and Corner lack for the other; Capt. Cambray charged
the Van of the Enemies Forlorn, Cornet JackÅ¿on flanke them, and upon their firÅ¿t charge exchanged ground, with the loÅ¿Å¿e of three men on both Å¿ides; but upon their preÅ¿ent wheeling, both parties received each other with a Å¿econd deÅ¿perate OnÅ¿et, who with great courage & reÅ¿olution kept their Å¿tations, diÅ¿puting the place with great gallantry; but at laÅ¿t our men being overpowred (by the coming on of a freÅ¿h Å¿upply of horÅ¿e) were forced to embrace an honourable retreat; the enemy purÅ¿ued to the very turn pikes, where they were Å¿oon welcomed by the Å¿ons of Mars, both from the mouth of the Canon and MuÅ¿quer, at which Volley, 7 of them were forced to yeeld obedience, and one man having his head Å¿eparated from his Å¿houlders by a Drake Å¿hot, his right hand man being Å¿omewhat Å¿tartled thereat, immediatly reply'd, The Divel's in theÅ¿e Round-heads for taking off heads. Whereupon the enemy Å¿oon deÅ¿erted engagement, leaving dead and wounded upon the place about 17, of our party five Å¿lain and two wounded.

Since the enemies receipt of the intelligence of the Lord Lieutenant Cramwels deÅ¿ignment for this bleeding City, they have Å¿omewhat awakened us with Å¿tronger all arms, and (as we heat) have entred into ProteÅ¿tation, to live and die, stand and fall together, and to Å¿ight it out to the laÅ¿t man, and that upon receipt of the foreÅ¿aid intelligence, Ormend called a Councell of Officers, at the head quarters neer Fingles, the reÅ¿ult was, whether they Å¿hould prepare for a Å¿torm, before his LordÅ¿hips landing, or whether they Å¿hould begin the City, Å¿treighten other GariÅ¿ons, take in what they could and then randezvouz and draw into a Body, and give him battell at his landing: Upon mature deliberation thereon, it was unanimoÅ¿ly declared by moÅ¿t of that PopiÅ¿h and Prelaticall faction. That if he Å¿et footing there they wold fight him; in the mean time they would uÅ¿e their utmoÅ¿t endeavours
for the reducing of thoÅ¿e GarriÅ¿ons which the Parliament had in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.

But the thing that our Souldiery are moÅ¿t doubtfull and dubious of, is, that they fear the enemy will not give them a field upon the additionall forces landing, but that they wil rather betake themÅ¿elves to the Bogs and Woods.

And although we cannot but repreÅ¿ent our Å¿elves in a very Å¿ad condition (without timely relief) yet we cannot but exceedingly rejoyce at the gallantry of faithfull Col. Jones our Governour, under Å¿uch a Å¿tate, in his RepreÅ¿entation to the Lord Inchiquin; the Å¿um whereof followeth:

My Lord, As for that conference by your LordÅ¿hip now propounded and deÅ¿ired, it cannot be in prudence admitted, eÅ¿pacially in matters of this conÅ¿equence, and in times when Å¿uch debatings muÅ¿t needs be dangerous, as being Å¿ubject to whatÅ¿oever conÅ¿tructions and miÅ¿conÅ¿tructions alÅ¿o. But Å¿o well am I Å¿atisfied in the juÅ¿tice of my cauÅ¿e (whereupon the Lords bleÅ¿Å¿ing hath dwelt viÅ¿ibly, as I truÅ¿t it doth) and I am fixed to my juÅ¿t principles, whence by letters and diÅ¿courÅ¿es I am not to be removed; and I wiÅ¿h heartily your LordÅ¿hip had done Å¿o likewiÅ¿e.
Your Sword hath been (I confeÅ¿Å¿e) proÅ¿perous, but remember, my Lord, the cauÅ¿e in which you then appeared, the Å¿ame with this now by us here maintained, againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e bloudy Rebels.
But now is your LordÅ¿hip with them moÅ¿t unhappily joyned, to the admiration of thoÅ¿e who formerly knew your LordÅ¿hips profeÅ¿Å¿ions, &c.
Our Governour is very vigilant, and reÅ¿olved not to Å¿urrender upon any conditions. By the next I Å¿hall impart my Å¿elf more fully.

div.head: A RepreÅ¿entation of the proceedings of the Royall par â¢â¢ for CHARLES the Å¿econd.
div.p: THe Royall p â¢â¢â¢â¢ begins to declare very high for the declared King of Scots, againÅ¿t the preÅ¿ent authority of this Nation, and inÅ¿ulteth very much o â¢â¢ the well affected party, Å¿aying, That Charles Å¿hall be ãâã and woe be unto them that Å¿ayes againÅ¿t it; and upon ãâã day laÅ¿t Å¿everall Gentlemen extraordinary well moun â¢â¢ , and gallantly armed) of quality came to MancheÅ¿ter, and there proclaimed Prince Charles (eldeÅ¿t Son to Charles the firÅ¿t) King of England, Scotland, and Ireland; which done they departed the town without interruption or moleÅ¿tation; and from thence went to Wiggin, where they cauÅ¿ed the like to be proclaimed as formerly; and from thence they went to Kendall in WeÅ¿tmerland, where they met with Å¿ome oppoÅ¿ition at the proclaiming therof; the manner thus: A party of the Parliaments Souldiers having received information of their deli â¢â¢â¢ , prepared to received them, and even in the nick of time came in upon them, diÅ¿puted the place with Å¿everall Vollies and at laÅ¿t the Royall party Å¿eeing themÅ¿elves overpowred in number, beco â¢â¢ themÅ¿elves to a retreat, and by the Å¿wiftneÅ¿Å¿e of their horÅ¿es made an honourable retreat, and eÅ¿caped, with the loÅ¿Å¿e of two men.
One Col. Walton is Å¿aid to be the Commander in chiefe of the Royall party, and leaves no means unaÅ¿Å¿ayed for the advancing of his young MaÅ¿ters CauÅ¿e.

LieceÅ¿ter 9 July, 1649. Sir, We hear that the Royall party about Newark upon Trent hath lately proclaimed Prince
Charles King of Great Britain, France and Ireland,

ration; but its believe, that if they poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s on this treaÅ¿onable deÅ¿ign, as the Parliament of England hath ãâã i â¢ , they will Å¿uddenly receive a ãâ¦ã .

We likewiÅ¿e hear, that a Squadron of the Princes Å¿hips hath fallen on the Northern Fleet, and that they have taken about 30 Å¿hips laden with comodities for London, and diÅ¿pierÅ¿ed the Convoy: this Victory (it's Å¿aid) fell to Capt. ãâ¦ã Admiral to the Prince) ãâ¦ã carrying ãâ¦ã of Ordnance, called The ãâã of Dunkirk, formerly the King of Spain's Vice-admirall.
Since which time we hear, that Capt. Harris hath obtaind Å¿ome gallant atchievements at Sea, and that he hath taken three of the Princes Å¿hips, and Å¿unk two, with the loÅ¿Å¿e of eight men.

The K. of Denmark hath cauÅ¿ed to be proclaimed through all his Dominions, That whoÅ¿oever will take up Arms againÅ¿t the Parliament of England, they Å¿hall have free egreÅ¿Å¿e and regreÅ¿se into his Harbours, and may freely Å¿ecure within his Dominions any prize made vpon the EngliÅ¿h Å¿hips, belonging to the Parliament.
